"ABSTRACT": "The present review summarizes the current knowledge on the pharmacology of cannabinoids, with a focus on their therapeutic potential in pain management. Cannabinoids exert their analgesic effects through interaction with the endocannabinoid system, which consists of endogenous ligands, receptors, and enzymes. The two main receptors, CB1 and CB2, are expressed in the central and peripheral nervous system, as well as in immune cells. The endocannabinoid system plays a role in the modulation of pain transmission, inflammation, and neuroprotection. Several cannabinoids, including delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), cannabidiol (CBD), and synthetic agonists and antagonists, have been investigated for their analgesic properties in various experimental models of pain. This review provides an overview of the pharmacology of cannabinoids, their mechanisms of action, and their therapeutic potential in pain management."

used the duration of QRS interval prolongation, ventricular precontraction, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation as markers of arrhythmia to study the effects of C. pinnatifida Bunge (Shanzha) extract on digoxin-induced arrhythmias, and the results showed that the ventricular arrhythmias in the digoxin-induced experimental group of rats all decreased after the administration of C. pinnatifida Bunge (Shanzha) extract, indicating that the flavonoid glycoside and flavane polymers in C. pinnatifida Bunge (Shanzha) extract can antagonize digoxin-induced arrhythmias (Li and Huang, 2016), which may be related to their ability to dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, slow down the heart rhythm, and improve the cardiovascular system (Zhang et al., 2021).

"STUDY": The study described is an investigation on the effects of C. pinnatifida Bunge (Shanzha) extract on digoxin-induced arrhythmias in rats.

"C. pinnatifida Bunge (Shanzha)": The name of the plant used in the study.

"arrhythmias": Conditions characterized by irregular heartbeats.

"duration of QRS interval": A measure of the time it takes for an electrical impulse to travel through the heart from the atria to the ventricles and be recorded as a QRS complex in an electrocardiogram (ECG).

"ventricular precontraction": A phenomenon where the ventricular muscle contracts before the onset of the T wave in the ECG, which can lead to decreased efficiency of the heart pump.

"ventricular tachycardia": A type of arrhythmia characterized by a rapid, often irregular heart rate, usually more than 100 beats per minute.

"ventricular fibrillation": A life-threatening arrhythmia characterized by rapid, disorganized electrical activity in the ventricles, which can lead to cardiac arrest.

"digoxin": A cardiac glycoside medication used to treat heart failure and atrial fibrillation.

"extract": A substance obtained from a plant or other natural source, typically containing bioactive compounds.

"flavonoid glycoside": A type of flavonoid compound that contains a sugar molecule.

"flavane polymers": A type of flavanone compound that consists of multiple flavanone units linked together.

"dilate blood vessels": The ability of a substance to widen the diameter of blood vessels, which can improve blood flow and reduce blood pressure.

"lower blood pressure": A decrease in the pressure of blood in the arteries, which can reduce the workload on the heart and improve cardiac function.

Title: Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of New Oral Anticoagulants: A Review

Authors: X. Zhang, Y. Liu, Z. Wang

Journal: Journal of Pharmacy and Pharmacology

Year: 2021

Volume: 73

Issue: 11

Pages: 1234-1245

Abstract: In this review, we summarize the current knowledge of the pharmacokinetics (PK) and pharmacodynamics (PD) of new oral anticoagulants (NOACs), including apixaban, rivaroxaban, and edoxaban.

Text:

The new oral anticoagulants (NOACs) have become the first-line therapy for various indications due to their superior safety and efficacy profiles compared to warfarin (Xie et al., 2012). In this review, we summarize the current knowledge of the pharmacokinetics (PK) and pharmacodynamics (PD) of NOACs, including apixaban, rivaroxaban, and edoxaban.

Apixaban:
Apixaban is a selective and reversible factor Xa inhibitor (Bauer et al., 2008). Its PK profile is characterized by a short half-life (12 hours) and a large volume of distribution (Vd) (approximately 12 L/kg) (Bauer et al., 2008). Apixaban is mainly metabolized by glucuronidation (Bauer et al., 2008).

Rivaroxaban:
Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor with a PK profile characterized by a short half-life (6-9 hours) and a moderate Vd (approximately 40 L) (Bauer et al., 2008). Rivaroxaban is mainly metabolized by the liver through glucuronidation and CYP3A4 (Bauer et al., 2008).

Edoxaban:
Edoxaban is a selective and reversible factor Xa inhibitor with a PK profile characterized by a long half-life (approximately

3; Table 8) in a manner consistent with the literature (Ring et al., 1996; Suzuki et al., 2002; Emoto et al., 2003; Walsky et al., 2006; VandenBrink et al., 2011; Zhao et al., 2012; Thu et al., 2017).

The present study was designed as a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new drug (Compound X) in the treatment of chronic pain (pain syndrome) in patients with fibromyalgia (fibromyalgia patients). The trial included 120 fibromyalgia patients who were randomly assigned to receive either Compound X or placebo for a period of 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the change in pain intensity as assessed by a visual analog scale (pain intensity). Secondary outcome measures included the change in sleep quality, fatigue levels, and quality of life (sleep quality, fatigue, quality of life).

The results showed that Compound X significantly reduced pain intensity compared to placebo (p < 0.05). However, this difference did not reach statistical significance in the analysis of sleep quality, fatigue levels, and quality of life (sleep quality: p = 0.12, fatigue: p = 0.08, quality of life: p = 0.06). The adverse events were similar in both groups.

It is important to note that no statistical significance was observed in the analysis of sleep quality, fatigue levels, and quality of life despite the significant reduction in pain intensity. This may suggest that the improvement in pain may not have led to a meaningful improvement in other aspects of the patients' condition.

"COMPOUND X": New drug being tested for the treatment of chronic pain in fibromyalgia patients.

"FIBROMYALGIA PATIENTS": Individuals diagnosed with fibromyalgia who participated in the clinical trial.

Authors: X. Liu, Y. Zhang, J. Wang, H. Chen, and Z. Zhao

Journal: Pharmacology Research

Year: 2003

Volume: 46

Issue: 2

Pages: 151-158

Study: In vitro and in vivo

Participants: Rats

Entities:

1. Simvastatin: A statin drug used for lowering cholesterol levels in the blood.
2. Connexin 43: A protein that forms gap junctions in cardiomyocytes, allowing for the electrical and metabolic coupling between cells.
3. Cardioprotection: The ability of a drug or intervention to protect the heart from damage or injury.
4. Rat myocardium: The heart muscle tissue in rats.
5. In vitro: Experiments performed in a controlled laboratory environment, outside of a living organism.
6. In vivo: Experiments performed within a living organism.
7. Cholesterol: A lipid that plays a crucial role in the structure and function of cell membranes.
8. Statins: A class of drugs that inhibit the HMG-CoA reductase enzyme, which is involved in the production of cholesterol in the liver.
9. HMG-CoA reductase: An enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) to mevalonate, which is a key step in the synthesis of cholesterol.
10. Gap junctions: Structures that connect the cytoplasm of adjacent cells, allowing for the exchange of ions, metabolites, and signaling molecules between cells.
11. Cardiomyocytes: The muscle cells that make up the heart.
12. Electrical coupling: The process by which electrical signals are transmitted between cardiomyocytes, allowing for coordinated contraction of the heart.

The expression of the human sodium-glucose cotransporter 1 (SGLT1) was upregulated in response to high glucose conditions [1, 2]. SGLT1 inhibitors, such as empagliflozin and canagliflozin, have been shown to improve glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) [3-5].

"STUDY": Clinical trials

Empagliflozin, a selective and potent inhibitor of SGLT1, reduced HbA1c levels by 0.6% to 1.2% compared to placebo in multiple clinical trials [3, 4]. Canagliflozin, another SGLT1 inhibitor, resulted in a reduction of HbA1c levels by 0.9% to 1.3% compared to placebo [5].

"STUDY": In vitro studies

The mechanism of action of SGLT1 inhibitors involves the inhibition of SGLT1-mediated glucose reabsorption in the proximal tubules of the kidney [6, 7]. This leads to an increase in urinary glucose excretion and a subsequent decrease in blood glucose levels [8].

"STUDY": In vivo studies

In animal models, SGLT1 inhibitors have been shown to improve glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity [9, 10]. In addition, they have been shown to have renoprotective effects by reducing albuminuria and preventing diabetic nephropathy [11, 12].

"STUDY": Clinical trials (human)

Empagliflozin and canagliflozin have also been shown to have cardiovascular benefits in clinical trials. The EMPA-REG OUTCOME trial demonstrated that empagliflozin reduced the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) by 14% compared to placebo in patients with T2DM and established cardiovascular disease [13]. The CANVAS trial showed that canagliflozin reduced the risk of MACE by 13% compared to placebo in patients with T2DM and at

A more detailed description of the regulatory environment in Europe, as well as its practical effects, can be found in the Bilia and Céu Costas review [13].

"REVIEW": Bilia and Céu Costas

The European Medicines Agency (EMA) is responsible for the scientific evaluation, supervision and safety monitoring of medicines developed by the pharmaceutical industry in the European Union (EU) [1]. The EMA's Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) is the primary body for the scientific evaluation of medicines [2]. The CHMP makes recommendations on marketing authorization, which are then adopted by the European Commission [3].

The regulatory environment in Europe has undergone significant changes in recent years, with the aim of increasing efficiency and transparency in the regulatory process [4]. One of the most notable changes has been the implementation of a centralized procedure for marketing authorization applications, which allows for a single application to be evaluated by the EMA on behalf of all EU member states [5].

Another important aspect of the European regulatory environment is the role of the European Medicines Agency's Network of Experts, which provides scientific advice to applicants during the development of new medicines [6]. The Network of Experts includes experts from various fields, including pharmacology, toxicology, and clinical medicine [7].

The practical effects of these changes have been significant. For example, the centralized procedure has led to a reduction in the time required for marketing authorization, with the average time for approval being around 21 months [8]. Additionally, the role of the European Medicines Agency's Network of Experts has facilitated more effective communication between applicants and regulatory authorities, leading to a more streamlined development process for new medicines [9].

In conclusion, the European Medicines Agency plays a crucial role in the regulatory environment for medicines in the European Union. The implementation of a centralized procedure for marketing authorization applications and the role of the European Medicines Agency's Network of Experts have led to increased efficiency and transparency in the regulatory process, resulting in a more streamlined development process for new medicines.
